Clooney foundation to fund schools for Syrian refugees

Show Caption Hide Caption George and Amal Clooney to donate $3.5 million to Syrian refugee children George and Amal Clooney have committed to help 3,000 Syrian refugee children go to school in Lebanon. USA TODAY



NEW YORK — George Clooney's charitable foundation is planning to open seven public schools for Syrian refugee children.

The Clooney Foundation for Justice announced a new partnership Monday with Google, HP and UNICEF to provide education for more than 3,000 refugee children in Lebanon.

George Clooney and his wife, British human-rights lawyer Amal Alamuddin Clooney, who was born in Lebanon, said in a statement Monday that the foundation's commitment of more than $2 million toward education for Syrian refugees aims to prevent thousands of young people from becoming "a lost generation."

"They have been victims of geography and circumstance, but that doesn't mean there isn't hope," the couple wrote in a statement provided to The AP. "Our goal with this initiative is to help provide Syrian refugee children with an education and put them on a path to be the future leaders their generation desperately needs."

A UNICEF spokesman described the couple's support as "investing the future of the entire region."

George and Amal Clooney established the Clooney Foundation for Justice last year to support equity in courtrooms, classrooms and communities around the world.

The couple just celebrated the birth of their twins in June. Their witty statement, issued through their spokesman, Stan Rosenfield, on June 6, said, "This morning Amal and George welcomed Ella and Alexander Clooney into their lives. Ella, Alexander and Amal are all healthy, happy and doing fine. George is sedated and should recover in a few days."
